text: So basically I want to make this. This is my sketch. I have made some prototypes out of corrugated but the gears aren't quite right or strong enough. I would be looking to assemble this through laser cut and 3d printing I just have no clue how to get the gears to work! any tips or help would be greatly appreciated!!!

elements.text: So basically I want to make this. This is my sketch. I have made some prototypes out of corrugated but the gears aren't quite right or strong enough. I would be looking to assemble this through laser cut and 3d printing I just have no clue how to get the gears to work! any tips or help would be greatly appreciated!!!

text: Awesome! for the gears, looks like you're trying to transmit motion in 90 degrees, in that the crank is on the side of the setup and the barrel is facing the front? I think simple planar gears usually do not to a great job transmitting motion in 90 degrees, but what you can take a look at is bevel gears? they are specifically made for the purpose. given their 3D geometries, it is probably better to 3D-print them. Are you familiar with any CAD software, like Solidworks, Rhino, etc?

elements.text: Awesome! for the gears, looks like you're trying to transmit motion in 90 degrees, in that the crank is on the side of the setup and the barrel is facing the front? I think simple planar gears usually do not to a great job transmitting motion in 90 degrees, but what you can take a look at is bevel gears? they are specifically made for the purpose. given their 3D geometries, it is probably better to 3D-print them. Are you familiar with any CAD software, like Solidworks, Rhino, etc?

text:
There are also existing bevel gears set that you can purchase, but you'd be limited to the pre-made shapes and sizes. A simple search on Amazon gives me this: <https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-Replacement-Spiral-Makita-Grinder/dp/B00857RX2I/ref=sr_1_20?dchild=1&keywords=bevel+gear&qid=1615848683&sr=8-20>
Usually, these premade sets do a much better job in reducing friction and maximizing efficiency compared to 3D-printed ones tho

text:
So, to make a 3D-print request, you'll need file(s) in .STL format. you can prepare the files by either using a CAD software (if you have no prior experience you can start with this:<https://www.tinkercad.com/>). Some CAD software like Solidworks have built-in helper features to create bevel gears quickly, but they usually have a relatively steep learning curve. Alternatively, you can find existing files online. The website I would recommend is <http://Thingiverse.com|Thingiverse.com> (and an example of 3D-printable bevel gears: <https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575/files>).
As for attaching the barrel to the gear, I think it depends on how much time you are willing to spend to learn how to design or modify existing gear models to include mounting holes? You can also use hot glue/epoxy/superglue. You can also look for turntables as an easy way to constrain the barrel to rotate relative to the box body.

attachments.title: Tinkercad | From mind to design in minutes
attachments.text: Tinkercad is a free, easy-to-use app for 3D design, electronics, and coding.
attachments.fallback: Tinkercad: Tinkercad | From mind to design in minutes

attachments.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears by GregFrost
attachments.text: This OpenSCAD script provides modules for both Spur and Bevel Gears. It has some major enhancements over my original gear script <http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3534>. It uses some of the spur gear nomenclature code from TheOtherRob <http://github.com/TheOtherRob/MCAD> with my own code for generating the involute teeth. The bevel gear is also my own work. Thanks also to elmom for some enhancements to my original gear script <http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3547>. Enhancements include the Bevel gear module, backlash settings, parameterised number of facets for the involute curve and whole of tooth generation to avoid some of the issues the original script had when mirroring a half tooth. The STLs provided are not intended for direct use, but instead show examples of what can be done with the parametric script. Parametric Involute Spur Gears take the following parameters:number_of_teethcircular_pitch or diametral_pitch: controls the size of the teeth (and hence the size of the gear).pressure_angle: controls the shape of the teeth.clearance: The gap between the root between teeth and the teeth point on a meshing gear.gear_thickness: the thickness of the gear plate.rim_thickness: the thickness of the gear at the rim (including the teeth).rim_width: radial distance from the root of the teeth to the inside of the rim.hub_thickness: the thickness of the section around the bore.hub_diameterbore_diameter: size of the hole in the middlecircles: the number of circular holes to cut in the gear plate.backlash: the space between this the back of this gears teeth and the front of its meshing gear\\'s teeth when the gear is correctly spaced from it.twist: for making helical gears.involute_facets: the number of facets in one side of the involute tooth shape. If this is omitted it will be 1/4 of $fn. If $fn is not set, it will be 5. Parametric Involute Profile Bevel (Conical) Gears take the following parameters:number_of_teethcone_distance: The distance from the pitch apex to the outside pitch diameter.face_width: The length of the teeth.outside_circular_pitch: The circular pitch at the outside pitch diameter.pressure_angle: Defines the shape of the teeth.clearance: Gap between the tip of the teeth on one gear and the root of the teeth on another meshing gear.bore_diameter: The size of the hole in the middle.gear_thickness: The thickness of the gear for bevel_gear_back_cone finish (see below).backlash: Makes the tooth width smaller to make a gap between teeth of correctly spaced gears to allow for manufacturing tolerances.involute_facets: As for spur gears.finish: Specify either bevel_gear_flat(0) or bevel_gear_back_cone(1). If you don't specify this parameter you will get a flat gear for pitch angles less than 45 degrees and a back cone gear for pitch angles greater than 45 degrees. The example shows both with the small gear being the flat one. Update: v5.0 Implements backlash for bevel gears (This was not working in v4.0).
attachments.fallback: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears by GregFrost

As for attaching the barrel to the gear, I think it depends on how much time you are willing to spend to learn how to design or modify existing gear models to include mounting holes? You can also use hot glue/epoxy/superglue. You can also look for turntables as an easy way to constrain the barrel to rotate relative to the box body.

text: Yes - there are a number of ways you can do it. You can get a hole on the center of the gear (better if it's already in the 3d model or if you ordered existing gear with a hole pre-drilled), put a hole on the outer box structure, and use a short piece of wooden dowel cut to length to go through the hole in the box and fixate it to the gear. Then you can attach 3D-printed, laser-cut, or purchased crank to the outside of the wooden dowel and complete the mechanism - does that make sense?

elements.text: Yes - there are a number of ways you can do it. You can get a hole on the center of the gear (better if it's already in the 3d model or if you ordered existing gear with a hole pre-drilled), put a hole on the outer box structure, and use a short piece of wooden dowel cut to length to go through the hole in the box and fixate it to the gear. Then you can attach 3D-printed, laser-cut, or purchased crank to the outside of the wooden dowel and complete the mechanism - does that make sense?

text: it would be difficult to print the gear and the crank in one-piece. The best practice for 3D printing is to have some part of a 3D model that is flat in order for the model to be easily built off from the print bed. a part with geometric features all around would be difficult to orient. a single gear, on the other hand, is easier to print because there's at least one flat side that you can lay it flushed to the printbed.

elements.text: it would be difficult to print the gear and the crank in one-piece.
